titleStmt.title: John Doyle v. William Billings. Recognizance

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: John Doyle v. William Billings. Recognizance
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the District Court, Of the Second Judicial District of Washington Territory, holding terms at Olympia for the Counties of Thurston and Mason
Territory of Washington vs. John Doyle

We, John Doyle, as principal and Charles Farnell, Robert Irving and as sureties acknowledge to owe and be indebted to the Territory of Washington in the sum of fifteen hundred dollars: That is to say, the said John Doyle in the full sum of fifteen hundred dollars. The said Charles Farnell in the sum of One thousand dollars. The said Robert Irving in the sum of Six hundred dollars.

Signed and sealed this 1st day of July 1884. The conditions of this obligation are as follows. Whereas, on the 19th day of June 1884 by com- mitment issued by N J Ross Justice of the Peace in and for Mason County W.T. the above bonder John Doyle was committed to the Jail of Thurston County upon a charge of obstructing the Union River Logging Railroad on the 14th day of June 1884 in Mason County. And whereas said John Doyle has been ordered let tot bail in the sum of fifteen hundred dollars, by the Honorable Judge of the Second Judicial District, Now therefore if the said John Doyle shall be and appear before the District Court of the Second Judicial District to be begun and holden at the city of Olympia on the first Monday in December 1884, and shall appear from day to day and from term to term until otherwise ordered by said Court, then this bond shall be void; otherwise in full force and effect. To the conditions of this bond we severally bind on heirs and assigns forthfully by these presents. Witness our hands and seals as the date first herein written.
Charles Farnell Seal Robert Irving Seal John Doyle Seal
Territory of Washington County of Thurston } ss

Charles Farnell Robert Irving being severally duly sworn, each for himself says, I am a citizen of Washington Territory and am worth the sum set opposite my name in the foregoing bond over and above all exemptions and liabilities.
Subscribed and sworn to before me July 1 1884 D P Ballard Notary Public
Territory of Washington vs. John Doyle
Recognizance Approved and Received and Filed Jul 1 1884 R.G O'Bruin Clerk
